content.text:
Please analyze this codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file, which will be given to future instances of Claude Code to operate in this repository.
            
What to add:
1. Commands that will be commonly used, such as how to build, lint, and run tests. Include the necessary commands to develop in this codebase, such as how to run a single test.
2. High-level code architecture and structure so that future instances can be productive more quickly. Focus on the "big picture" architecture that requires reading multiple files to understand

Usage notes:
- If there's already a CLAUDE.md, suggest improvements to it.
- When you make the initial CLAUDE.md, do not repeat yourself and do not include obvious instructions like "Provide helpful error messages to users", "Write unit tests for all new utilities", "Never include sensitive information (API keys, tokens) in code or commits" 
- Avoid listing every component or file structure that can be easily discovered
- Don't include generic development practices
- If there are Cursor rules (in .cursor/rules/ or .cursorrules) or Copilot rules (in .github/copilot-instructions.md), make sure to include the important parts.
- If there is a README.md, make sure to include the important parts. 
- Do not make up information such as "Common Development Tasks", "Tips for Development", "Support and Documentation" unless this is expressly included in other files that you read.
- Be sure to prefix the file with the following text:

```
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
```
I'll analyze the codebase to understand its structure and create a comprehensive CLAUDE.md file. Let me start by exploring the repository structure and key files.

todos.content: Explore repository structure and identify key directories
Check for existing documentation (README, package.json, etc.)
Analyze build system and development commands
Understand code architecture and key components
Check for existing rules files (.cursorrules, etc.)
Create CLAUDE.md file with findings

content.content: Todos have been modified successfully. Ensure that you continue to use the todo list to track your progress. Please proceed with the current tasks if applicable

source "https://rubygems.org"

# Bundle edge Rails instead: gem "rails", github: "rails/rails", branch: "main"
gem "rails", "~> 8.0.0", ">= 8.0.0.1"
# Use sqlite3 as the database for Active Record
gem "sqlite3", ">= 2.1"
# Use the Puma web server [https://github.com/puma/puma]
gem "puma", ">= 5.0"
# Build JSON APIs with ease [https://github.com/rails/jbuilder]
# gem "jbuilder"

# Use Active Model has_secure_password [https://guides.rubyonrails.org/active_model_basics.html#securepassword]
# gem "bcrypt", "~> 3.1.7"

# Windows does not include zoneinfo files, so bundle the tzinfo-data gem
gem "tzinfo-data", platforms: %i[ windows jruby ]

# Reduces boot times through caching; required in config/boot.rb
gem "bootsnap", require: false

# Use Rack CORS for handling Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS), making cross-origin Ajax possible
# gem "rack-cors"

gem "active_operation", "~> 1.0"

group :development, :test do
  gem "rspec-rails", "~> 7.0"
  gem "factory_bot_rails", "~> 6.0"
  gem "faker", "~> 3.0"

  # See https://guides.rubyonrails.org/debugging_rails_applications.html#debugging-with-the-debug-gem
  gem "debug", platforms: %i[ mri windows ], require: "debug/prelude"

  # Static analysis for security vulnerabilities [https://brakemanscanner.org/]
  gem "brakeman", require: false

  # Omakase Ruby styling [https://github.com/rails/rubocop-rails-omakase/]
  gem "rubocop-rails-omakase", require: false
end

group :test do
  gem "shoulda-matchers", "~> 6.0"
end

Rails.application.routes.draw do
  # Define your application routes per the DSL in https://guides.rubyonrails.org/routing.html

  # Reveal health status on /up that returns 200 if the app boots with no exceptions, otherwise 500.
  # Can be used by load balancers and uptime monitors to verify that the app is live.
  get "up" => "rails/health#show", as: :rails_health_check

  # Defines the root path route ("/")
  # root "posts#index"

  resources :users
  resources :downloaded_albums, except: [:destroy]
  resources :downloaded_files, except: [:destroy]
end

  VALID_FILE_TYPES = %w(GIF JPEG PNG).freeze

  belongs_to :downloaded_album

  validates :filename, presence: true

# frozen_string_literal: true
class CreateUser < ApplicationOperation
  input :name, accepts: String, type: :keyword, required: true
  input :email_address, accepts: String, type: :keyword, required: true

  def execute
    ActiveRecord::Base.transaction do
      user = User.create!(user_params)
      user.downloaded_albums.create!(title: "Default Album", default: true)
      user
    end
  rescue ActiveRecord::RecordInvalid => error
    halt(error.record)
  end

  private

  def user_params
    @user_params ||= {
      name: name,
      email_address: email_address
    }
  end
end

ActiveRecord::Schema[8.0].define(version: 2025_05_05_211131) do
  create_table "downloaded_albums", force: :cascade do |t|
    t.string "title"
    t.string "hostname"
    t.string "url"
    t.string "download_directory"
    t.integer "num_files"
    t.integer "user_id", null: false
    t.datetime "created_at", null: false
    t.datetime "updated_at", null: false
    t.boolean "default", default: false, null: false
    t.index ["user_id"], name: "index_downloaded_albums_on_user_id"

    t.string "filename"
    t.string "file_type"
    t.integer "num_bytes"
    t.string "url"
    t.integer "downloaded_album_id", null: false
    t.datetime "created_at", null: false
    t.datetime "updated_at", null: false
    t.index ["downloaded_album_id"], name: "index_downloaded_files_on_downloaded_album_id"
  end

  create_table "users", force: :cascade do |t|
    t.string "name"
    t.string "email_address"
    t.datetime "created_at", null: false
    t.datetime "updated_at", null: false
  end

  add_foreign_key "downloaded_albums", "users"
  add_foreign_key "downloaded_files", "downloaded_albums"
end

input.content:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Development Commands

### Running Tests
- `bundle exec rspec` - Run all tests
- `bundle exec rspec spec/models/` - Run model tests only
- `bundle exec rspec spec/operations/` - Run operation tests only
- `bundle exec rspec spec/requests/` - Run request tests only
- `bundle exec rspec spec/path/to/specific_spec.rb` - Run a specific test file

### Server Management
- `bundle exec rails server` or `bundle exec rails s` - Start development server
- `bundle exec rails console` or `bundle exec rails c` - Start Rails console

### Database Operations
- `bundle exec rails db:create` - Create database
- `bundle exec rails db:migrate` - Run migrations
- `bundle exec rails db:seed` - Seed database
- `bundle exec rails db:reset` - Drop, create, migrate, and seed database

### Code Quality
- `bundle exec rubocop` - Run Ruby linter (uses rubocop-rails-omakase)
- `bundle exec brakeman` - Run security scanner

## Architecture Overview

This is a Rails 8.0 API-only application that manages downloaded albums and files for users. The application follows a structured architecture with dedicated layers for different concerns.

### Core Models
- `User`: Represents system users with name and email_address
- `DownloadedAlbum`: Belongs to a user, contains metadata about downloaded albums including title, hostname, URL, download directory, and file count. Has a special "default" flag for system-created albums
- `DownloadedFile`: Belongs to a downloaded album, represents individual files with filename, file_type (GIF/JPEG/PNG), size in bytes, and source URL

### Operations Pattern
The application uses the `active_operation` gem for business logic encapsulation:
- `ApplicationOperation`: Base class for all operations
- `CreateUser`: Handles user creation with automatic default album creation
- `CreateDownloadedAlbum`: Manages album creation
- `CreateDownloadedFile`: Handles file record creation

### Controllers
- `ApplicationController`: Base API controller with simple authentication (uses `User.first` as current_user)
- Standard REST controllers for users, downloaded_albums, and downloaded_files
- Routes exclude destroy actions for albums and files

### Testing Setup
- Uses RSpec with FactoryBot for test data creation
- Shoulda Matchers for validation testing
- Transactional fixtures enabled
- Recent refactoring moved from FactoryBot.create to create operations

### Database
- SQLite3 for development and test environments
- Standard Rails migrations with foreign key constraints
- Schema includes proper indexing on foreign keys

## Key Patterns

### TDD Development
Always write failing tests first, then implement functionality, then refactor. The test suite is comprehensive with model, operation, request, and routing specs.

### Operation-Based Business Logic
Use operations for complex business logic rather than putting it directly in controllers or models. Operations handle transactions and error handling consistently.

### RESTful API Design
Controllers follow standard REST conventions with JSON responses. Authentication is simplified for this application.
